title: The moment every tourist fears
text:
Email a friend 
THE horrifying moment a bridge collapsed under the feet of a group of tourists, plunging them into the lake below, has been caught on camera. 
The four French travellers were on the Hopu Ruahine bridge at Te Urewera National Park in New Zealand when the cable “released” in the September 3 incident, the NZ Herald reports. 
A new video that has just been uploaded to YouTube by Adrien Whistle shows him walking along the suspension bridge with his friends Roland, Enzo and Effie, before disaster strikes. 
On his blog , Mr Whistle talks of hearing a “thud” before they are plunged into the water 8 metres below. 
Unbelievably they all escaped serious injury, but authorities have warned it was down to “good luck”. Down they go. Source: Supplied 
New Zealand’s Department of Conservation operations manager Mike Slater told the NZ Herald: “As a result (of the cable release) that has upset the stability of the bridge and that’s where people that were on the bridge have slipped off and fallen. 
“Fortunately other than some scratches and a little bit of bruising, they are not seriously injured.” 
He said the incident is being investigated. 
“An event such as this is extremely rare occurrence and we just need to understand in this particular case exactly what did happen.” 
Mr Slater said the bridge was last inspected in September last year, and had a full inspection 18 months ago by an engineer. Looking up at the bridge. Source: Supplied 
Meanwhile, Labour’s Conservation spokeswoman Ruth Dyson called for urgent action from the government. 
“It is a huge relief the four overseas tourists on the Lake Waikaremoana bridge that failed yesterday landed in water and were uninjured,” Ms Dyson said. “This is good luck not good management. Our reputation cannot rely on luck. 
“The cable failure is not only extremely concerning, it leaves New Zealand vulnerable to harmful tourism reaction.” 
The bridge was closed following the incident. 
news.com.au has contacted the Department of Conservation for comment.
